title: Ribble Way Walking Route

images.title: John S Turner / Long Lane and the Ribble Way
images.caption: Long Lane and the trail. This is the junction of Long Lane with the B6479. The signpost on the right reads 'BW Dale Head 2 3/4' and also carries the logo indicating that it is also the Ribble Way. In 2009 Long Lane is now classified as a BOAT - Byway open to all traffic.

images.title: John S Turner / A view from the Ribble Way
images.caption: A view from the Ribble Way above Winshaw contrasting the long grass of the open moorland with the short grass of the grazed fields.

images.title: John Illingworth / Ribble Way
images.caption: Limestone pasture above High Birkwith. The path dips into the narrow gill and can be seen emerging from the other side.

images.title: David Ashcroft / Ribble Way
images.caption: The River Ribble looking towards Preston from the footpath.

images.title: John Illingworth / The Ribble Way
images.caption: Near the source of the Ribble on Gayle Moor. The track is to be part of the Pennine Bridleway and has been given a surface suitable for that purpose.

images.title: John S Turner / The River Ribble from the Ribble Way
images.caption: A view of the tranquil River Ribble from the Ribble Way as they both head south for Settle. Hard to imagine this view is only 150 metres south of Stainforth Force. The grid line at the edge of the square runs from behind the wall on the left, across the centre of the photo.

images.title: John S Turner / Coppy Gill downstream from the Ribble Way
images.caption: Coppy Gill downstream from the trail. Looking west along Coppy Gill from where the Ribble Way crosses it.

images.title: John S Turner / View from a Stile on the Ribble Way
images.caption: View from a Stile on the trail. This view is from the top of the stile on the Ribble Way seen. It shows typical Dales scenery with pasture, stone walls and small limestone outcrops. The trail continues over the fell to the right.

description: Follow the River Ribble through the beautiful Ribble Valley from its mouth at Longton, near Preston, to the source at Gayle Moor in Yorkshire. You start at Longton just to the west of Preston and follow the river through Ribchester and Clitheroe, before reaching Gisburn. The path then crosses from Lancashire into Yorkshire before passing through the stunning Yorkshire Dales national park and finishing at the source at Gavel Moor near Ribblehead and the magnificent Ribblehead Viaduct. The route passes through a variety of landscapes including tidal marsh, open moorland and limestone gorges. Highlights on the route include the beautiful area around Hurst Green. Around here you can pick up the where you can pick up the Tolkien Trail. The literary trail explores an area of the Ribble Valley connected with the Lord of the Rings trilogy.
